scenarios.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
scenarios.description: Simulates use of non-application layer protocols for C2 communications to test network monitoring capabilities.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may use an OSI non-application layer protocol for communication between host and C2 server or among infected hosts within a network. The list of possible protocols is extensive.

scenarios.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
scenarios.description: Downloads malicious files and attempts execution to test detection of tool transfer and execution.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may transfer tools or other files from an external system into a compromised environment. Tools may be transferred from an external adversary controlled system through the command and control channel.

scenarios.name: Possible C2 via dnscat2
scenarios.description: Downloads and executes a file named dnscat2 to simulate C2 communications over DNS.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may abuse command and script interpreters to execute commands, scripts, or binaries. These interfaces and languages provide ways of interacting with computer systems and are a common feature across many different platforms.

scenarios.name: Memory Dumping
scenarios.description: Simulates dumping process memory to extract credentials and test memory protection mechanisms.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may attempt to access credential material stored in the process memory of the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS). After a user logs on, the system generates and stores a variety of credential materials in LSASS process memory.

scenarios.name: Keylogging
scenarios.description: Simulates a keylogger to capture user credentials and test keystroke monitoring detection.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may log user keystrokes to intercept credentials as the user types them. Keylogging is likely to be used to acquire credentials for new access opportunities when OS Credential Dumping efforts are not effective.

scenarios.name: Disable Linux Audit Logs
scenarios.description: Simulates disabling Linux audit logs to evade detection and test audit system protection.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may disable security tools to avoid possible detection of their tools and activities. This can take the form of killing security software or event logging processes.

scenarios.name: Clear Command History
scenarios.description: Simulates clearing bash history to hide commands and test history protection mechanisms.
scenarios.fullDescription: In addition to clearing system logs, an adversary may clear the command history of a compromised account to conceal the actions undertaken during an intrusion.

scenarios.name: Path Interception
scenarios.description: Simulates modifying environment variables for path interception to test PATH monitoring.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking environment variables used to load libraries or by placing libraries in search locations that are listed in environment variables.

scenarios.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
scenarios.description: Employs various obfuscation techniques to evade detection mechanisms and test static analysis.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may attempt to make an executable or file difficult to discover or analyze by encrypting, encoding, or otherwise obfuscating its contents on the system or in transit.

scenarios.name: Process Injection
scenarios.description: Injects code into running processes to evade detection and test process monitoring capabilities.
scenarios.fullDescription: Process injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process. Running code in the context of another process may allow access to the process's memory, system/network resources, and possibly elevated privileges.

scenarios.name: System Information Discovery
scenarios.description: Simulates collection of detailed system information to test information gathering detection.
scenarios.fullDescription: An adversary may attempt to get detailed information about the operating system and hardware, including version, patches, hotfixes, service packs, and architecture.

scenarios.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
scenarios.description: Simulates collection of network configuration information to test network enumeration detection.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may look for details about the network configuration and settings of systems they access or through information discovery of remote systems.

scenarios.name: Network Service Discovery
scenarios.description: Simulates scanning for network services to identify open ports and test port scanning detection.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of services running on remote hosts, including those that may be vulnerable to remote software exploitation.

scenarios.name: System Network Connections Discovery
scenarios.description: Simulates discovering network connections to map network activity and test connection monitoring.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of network connections to or from the compromised system they are currently accessing or from remote systems by querying for information over the network.

scenarios.name: DNS reconnaissance or enumeration via DNSRecon
scenarios.description: Creates and executes a benign DNS reconnaissance script to simulate DNS enumeration activities.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of other systems by IP address, hostname, or other logical identifier on a network that may be used for Lateral Movement from the current system.
scenarios.command: run "DNS reconnaissance or enumeration via DNSRecon"
scenarios.fullCommand: ./snellen-0.2.1-x86_64 run "DNS reconnaissance or enumeration via DNSRecon"

scenarios.name: Unix Shell Execution
scenarios.description: Simulates executing suspicious commands via shell to test command execution monitoring.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may abuse Unix shell commands and scripts for execution. Unix shells are the primary command prompt on Linux and macOS systems, though many variations of the Unix shell exist.

scenarios.name: Python Script Execution
scenarios.description: Simulates executing a malicious Python script to test script execution detection.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may abuse Python commands and scripts for execution. Python is a very popular scripting/programming language, with capabilities to perform many functions.

scenarios.name: Advanced Command and Scripting Interpreter
scenarios.description: Executes malicious commands with various obfuscation and evasion techniques to test advanced detection.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may abuse command and script interpreters to execute commands, scripts, or binaries. These interfaces and languages provide ways of interacting with computer systems.

scenarios.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
scenarios.description: Simulates data exfiltration using alternative protocols like DNS or ICMP to test data loss prevention.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over a different protocol than that of the existing command and control channel.

scenarios.name: SSH Lateral Movement
scenarios.description: Simulates SSH lateral movement attempts to test lateral movement detection capabilities.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may use SSH to log into accessible remote systems using valid credentials to perform lateral movement or to move to a specific network segment.

scenarios.name: Registry Run Keys
scenarios.description: Simulates adding an entry to autorun locations in registry to test persistence detection.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may achieve persistence by adding a program to a startup folder or referencing it with a Registry run key.

scenarios.name: Startup Folder
scenarios.description: Places a script in a startup folder to achieve persistence and test startup monitoring.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may achieve persistence by adding a program to a startup folder or referencing it with a Registry run key.

scenarios.name: Cron Job
scenarios.description: Creates a cron job for persistence to test scheduled task monitoring capabilities.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may abuse task scheduling functionality to facilitate initial or recurring execution of malicious code.

scenarios.name: Create or Modify System Process
scenarios.description: Creates or modifies system services and processes for persistence to test service monitoring.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may create or modify system-level processes to repeatedly execute malicious payloads as part of persistence.

scenarios.name: Sudoers Modification
scenarios.description: Simulates modifying the sudoers file to grant elevated privileges and test privilege escalation detection.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may perform sudo caching and/or use the sudoers file to elevate privileges. Adversaries may do this to execute commands as other users or spawn processes with higher privileges.

scenarios.name: SUID Binary
scenarios.description: Simulates setting the SUID bit on a binary for privilege escalation to test SUID monitoring.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may perform sudo caching and/or use the sudoers file to elevate privileges. The sudo command allows a user to run programs with the security privileges of another user.
